mcq.q: Which of the following is NOT a principle behind transport layer services?
The Internet transport protocol that provides connectionless transport is called _______.
The Internet transport protocol that provides connection-oriented reliable transport is called _______.
The transport layer provides logical communication between _______ running on different hosts.
On the sender side, the transport layer breaks application messages into _______.
On the receiver side, the transport layer _______ segments back into messages.
The network layer provides communication between _______.
In the 'household analogy', hosts are equivalent to _______.
In the 'household analogy', processes are equivalent to _______.
The receiver's transport layer receives a segment from the _______ layer.
The process of passing a received message up to the correct application via a socket is called _______.
Which protocol provides reliable, in-order delivery?
Which protocol provides unreliable, unordered delivery?
Which TCP service prevents a fast sender from overwhelming a slow receiver?
Which TCP service slows down the sender to avoid overloading the entire network?
Which protocol would an online gaming application most likely choose?
opts: UDP, for speed and low latency
mcq.answer: UDP, for speed and low latency

mcq.q: An application sends and receives messages through a/an _______, which acts as a 'door' to the transport layer.
Which of the following is NOT a feature of TCP?
UDP is described as a no-frills extension of _______.
Which of these services is NOT available from Internet transport protocols?

tf.q: UDP is a connection-oriented transport protocol.
tf.correction: UDP provides connectionless transport.

tf.q: TCP provides reliable, in-order delivery.
The transport layer provides logical communication between hosts.
tf.correction: It provides logical communication between application processes.

tf.q: The sender's transport layer breaks application messages into segments.
The network layer provides communication between processes.
tf.correction: It provides communication between hosts.

tf.q: The transport layer relies on and enhances network layer services.
The sender's transport layer passes a created segment directly to the Link layer.
tf.correction: It passes the segment to IP (the network layer).

tf.q: The receiver's transport layer receives segments from the IP layer.
TCP provides congestion control and flow control.
UDP provides congestion control.
tf.correction: It is a 'no-frills' protocol; TCP provides congestion control.

tf.q: TCP provides connection setup.
A web browser (HTTP) is a suitable application for UDP.
tf.correction: Web browsing requires 100% reliability, so it uses TCP.

tf.q: Routers in the middle of the network typically inspect and process the transport layer header.
tf.correction: Routers are network layer devices; they only process the IP header and do not look at the transport layer.

tf.q: A transport-layer segment is created by adding a transport header (Th) to an application message.
Internet transport protocols like TCP and UDP offer bandwidth guarantees.
tf.correction: This service is not available from them.

mcq.q: The sender-side process of gathering data chunks from different sockets and adding transport headers is called _______.
The receiver-side process of using header info to deliver segments to the correct socket is called _______.
For connectionless demultiplexing (UDP), a socket is identified only by the _______.
For connection-oriented demultiplexing (TCP), a socket is identified by a _______.
Which of the following is NOT part of the TCP socket's 4-tuple identifier?
A single server process can support many simultaneous TCP sockets on the same port because each socket has a unique _______.
UDP is described as a _______ service.
Which of the following is a primary reason to use UDP?
Which application is a good candidate for using UDP?
The modern web protocol HTTP/3 is built on top of _______.
Which field in the UDP header specifies the length of the entire UDP segment (header + data)?
What is the primary purpose of the UDP checksum?
The UDP header consists of 4 fields, making its total size _______.
When a receiver computes a checksum that differs from the one in the segment's header, it indicates _______.
UDP is connectionless, which means there is no _______ between sender and receiver.
The port number range for well-known protocols (e.g., HTTP, FTP) is:
In UDP, reliability, if needed, is usually added at the _______.
UDP can send data as fast as the application desires because it _______.
The Internet checksum calculation treats the segment's content as a sequence of _______.
When adding two numbers in the checksum calculation, a carry-out bit is _______.
A key weakness of the Internet checksum is that it _______.

tf.q: Multiplexing happens at the receiving host.
tf.correction: Multiplexing happens at the sending host; demultiplexing happens at the receiver.

tf.q: UDP demultiplexing uses both the destination IP address and destination port number to identify the socket.
tf.correction: UDP demultiplexing uses only the destination port number.

tf.q: A TCP server can handle multiple client connections on the same destination port simultaneously.
UDP segments may be lost or delivered out-of-order.
One of UDP's main features is its robust congestion control mechanism.
tf.correction: UDP has no congestion control; it can send data as fast as the application desires.

tf.q: The lack of connection setup makes UDP faster than TCP for initial data transmission.
DNS is an application that typically runs over TCP.
tf.correction: DNS typically runs over UDP because it involves short, query-response transactions.

tf.q: The UDP checksum is calculated over the UDP header and the application data (payload).
The Internet checksum used by UDP is guaranteed to detect all possible bit flip errors.
tf.correction: The checksum is considered weak protection as some errors can cancel each other out and go undetected.

tf.q: If the computed checksum at the receiver equals the checksum value in the received segment, it proves that no errors occurred.
tf.correction: It means no errors were detected, but errors may still exist.

tf.q: The 'Source Port' field is a mandatory field in the UDP header.
tf.correction: The source port is needed if a reply is expected, but it is not strictly mandatory for a one-way message.

tf.q: The UDP 'Length' field includes the size of the header in its calculation.
TCP sockets are identified by the destination port number alone.
tf.correction: TCP sockets are identified by a 4-tuple (source IP/port, destination IP/port).

tf.q: Multiplexing and demultiplexing principles are only used in the transport layer.
tf.correction: These principles happen at multiple layers in the network stack.

tf.q: Reliability can be added to an application running over UDP at the application layer.
A datagram socket in UDP is created without requiring a connection setup.
UDP is called a 'best effort' service because it does not guarantee delivery.

mcq.q: What is the fundamental goal of a reliable data transfer (rdt) protocol?
opts: To provide a reliable channel over an unreliable network
To guarantee the fastest possible data transfer speed
To encrypt data packets for security
To select the shortest physical path for a packet
mcq.answer: To provide a reliable channel over an unreliable network

mcq.q: In the rdt protocol specifications, a Finite State Machine (FSM) is used to _______.
opts: Specify the sender and receiver behavior
mcq.answer: Specify the sender and receiver behavior

mcq.q: The rdt1.0 protocol assumes the underlying channel is _______.
To handle bit errors, the rdt2.0 protocol introduces _______.
In rdt2.1, what is added to solve the problem of corrupted ACKs/NAKs?
In a NAK-free protocol like rdt2.2, how does the sender detect a corrupted packet at the receiver?
opts: By receiving a duplicate ACK for the previous packet
The sender cannot detect corrupted packets
mcq.answer: By receiving a duplicate ACK for the previous packet

mcq.q: The primary mechanism introduced in rdt3.0 to handle packet loss is the _______.
A major drawback of 'Stop-and-Wait' protocols like rdt3.0 is _______.
opts: Very low sender utilization on high-speed links
mcq.answer: Very low sender utilization on high-speed links

mcq.q: The technique of allowing the sender to transmit multiple packets without waiting for an ACK is called _______.
In the Go-Back-N (GBN) protocol, a cumulative ACK, ACK(n), means _______.
opts: All packets up to and including 'n' have been received
mcq.answer: All packets up to and including 'n' have been received

mcq.q: In the Selective Repeat (SR) protocol, the receiver individually acknowledges _______.
opts: Only the first packet in the window

mcq.q: Scenario (GBN): Sender sends packets 0, 1, 2, 3 (N=4). Pkt 2 is lost. Receiver gets pkts 0, 1, then 3. What action does the receiver take for pkt 3?
Scenario (SR): Sender sends packets 0, 1, 2, 3 (N=4). Pkt 2 is lost. Receiver gets pkts 0, 1, then 3. What action does the receiver take for pkt 3?
Scenario (rdt3.0): Sender sends pkt 1. The ACK for pkt 1 is lost. What happens next?
Scenario (GBN): Sender has sent packets 5, 6, 7. The timer for packet 5 expires. What does the sender retransmit?
Scenario (SR): Sender has sent packets 5, 6, 7. The timer for packet 5 expires, while ACKs for 6 and 7 have been received. What does the sender retransmit?
Scenario (rdt2.1): Receiver is expecting packet 0. It receives a corrupted packet. What does it send back?
Scenario (GBN): Receiver has received up to packet 3. It then receives packet 5. Which ACK does it send?
The primary advantage of Selective Repeat over Go-Back-N is that it _______.

tf.q: In rdt2.0, a sender in the 'Wait for ACK or NAK' state will return to the 'Wait for call from above' state upon receiving an ACK.
A single bit for sequence numbers (0/1) is sufficient for any pipelined protocol.
tf.correction: This is only sufficient for Stop-and-Wait protocols; pipelining requires a larger range of sequence numbers.

tf.q: rdt3.0 is considered a functionally correct reliable data transfer protocol.
Pipelining decreases sender utilization because it increases the number of in-flight packets.
tf.correction: Pipelining dramatically increases sender utilization by keeping the network channel busy.

tf.q: The receiver in Go-Back-N must buffer out-of-order packets.
tf.correction: The GBN receiver is simple; it discards all out-of-order packets.

tf.q: In Selective Repeat, a sender maintains a conceptual timer for each unacknowledged packet.
Scenario: In rdt2.1, a sender sends packet 1. The receiver gets it and sends ACK1, but the ACK1 is corrupted. The sender will retransmit packet 1.
tf.correction: The sender retransmits upon receiving a garbled response. The receiver will then see a duplicate packet 1 and re-send ACK1.

tf.q: Scenario: In Go-Back-N, if the sender receives an ACK for a packet that is not the oldest unacknowledged packet, it will not advance its window.
tf.correction: GBN uses cumulative ACKs, so the window only moves forward when the oldest packet (send_base) is acknowledged.

tf.q: The Selective Repeat receiver delivers packets to the application layer as soon as they are received, even if they are out of order.
tf.correction: The SR receiver buffers out-of-order packets and only delivers a contiguous sequence of packets to the upper layer.

tf.q: Scenario: In Selective Repeat, the sender receives an ACK for packet 5, which is within its window. This action alone is enough to make the sender's window slide forward.
tf.correction: The sender's window only slides forward when the oldest unacknowledged packet (send_base) is acknowledged.

mcq.q: Which of the following best describes how TCP views the data it sends?
opts: As a stream of individual messages

mcq.q: In the TCP segment header, what does the 'acknowledgement number' field signify?
opts: The sequence number of the last packet received
The sequence number of the next byte the receiver expects
The total number of bytes received so far
The sequence number of the current segment
mcq.answer: The sequence number of the next byte the receiver expects

mcq.q: The maximum amount of data that can be placed in a single TCP segment is known as the _______.
The primary purpose of the 'receive window' (rwnd) field in the TCP header is for _______.
How does TCP set its retransmission timeout value?
opts: It is a fixed value configured by the user
It is always twice the last measured RTT
It is dynamically calculated based on EstimatedRTT and DevRTT
It is negotiated during the 3-way handshake
mcq.answer: It is dynamically calculated based on EstimatedRTT and DevRTT

mcq.q: What triggers a 'Fast Retransmit'?
opts: The expiration of the retransmission timer
The receipt of a single NAK packet
The receipt of three duplicate ACKs for the same data
The receipt of a segment with a bad checksum
mcq.answer: The receipt of three duplicate ACKs for the same data

mcq.q: The 3-way handshake is necessary to avoid which problem?
opts: Half-open connections from delayed, old requests
mcq.answer: Half-open connections from delayed, old requests

mcq.q: Which TCP flag is used to abruptly terminate a connection, often in response to an error?
Scenario: A TCP client sends a SYN packet with `Seq=500`. What will the server's SYN-ACK response contain?
Scenario: Host A sends a segment with `Seq=1000` containing 100 bytes of data to Host B. If it is received correctly, what ACK number will Host B send back?
Scenario: A receiver has a buffer (RcvBuffer) of 4096 bytes. The application has read 1024 bytes from it, leaving 3072 bytes of data. What `rwnd` value will the receiver advertise?

Scenario: Host A sends three segments to B: `Seq=200` (100 bytes), `Seq=300` (100 bytes), and `Seq=400` (100 bytes). The segment with `Seq=300` is lost. Host B receives the segments with `Seq=200` and `Seq=400`. What ACK will B send after receiving the segment with `Seq=400`?

Scenario: A TCP receiver gets an in-order segment with the expected sequence number, and all previous data has already been acknowledged. According to RFC 5681, what is the recommended receiver action?
opts: Discard the segment as it might be a duplicate
Wait up to 500ms for the next segment before sending an ACK
mcq.answer: Wait up to 500ms for the next segment before sending an ACK

mcq.q: Scenario (Lost ACK): Host A sends a segment with `Seq=92` (8 bytes). Host B receives it and sends `ACK=100`, but this ACK is lost. What does Host A do when its timer expires?
opts: It sends the next segment with `Seq=100`
It waits for a different ACK from Host B
It terminates the connection with a FIN packet

mcq.q: Scenario (Lost ACK Follow-up): After the timeout, Host A retransmits the `Seq=92` segment. Host B receives this duplicate segment. What is Host B's correct action?
opts: Accept the duplicate data and send `ACK=108`
Send a NAK because it's a duplicate
Discard the duplicate data and re-send `ACK=100`
mcq.answer: Discard the duplicate data and re-send `ACK=100`

mcq.q: Scenario (Cumulative ACK): Host A sends `Seq=92` (8 bytes), then `Seq=100` (20 bytes). The first response, `ACK=100`, is lost. Shortly after, the second response, `ACK=120`, arrives successfully at Host A. How does Host A interpret this?
opts: It concludes only the second segment was received and waits for a timeout on the first
It concludes both segments were received correctly thanks to the cumulative nature of the ACK
It ignores `ACK=120` because it is out of order
It immediately retransmits the segment with `Seq=92`
mcq.answer: It concludes both segments were received correctly thanks to the cumulative nature of the ACK

mcq.q: Scenario (Premature Timeout): Host A sends `Seq=92` (8 bytes) and `Seq=100` (20 bytes). Due to network delay, the ACKs are slow to return. Host A's timer for `Seq=92` expires. What is the immediate result?
opts: Host A retransmits both segments `Seq=92` and `Seq=100`
Host A only retransmits `Seq=92` because its timer expired
Host A waits longer because it knows the ACKs are just delayed
mcq.answer: Host A only retransmits `Seq=92` because its timer expired

mcq.q: Scenario (Premature Timeout Follow-up): After the premature timeout and retransmission of `Seq=92`, the original (but delayed) `ACK=100` and `ACK=120` finally arrive at Host A. What will Host A's `SendBase` be after processing `ACK=120`?
opts: It will not change until the retransmitted packet is acknowledged

tf.q: TCP sequence numbers count segments, not bytes.
tf.correction: TCP uses a byte-stream paradigm, and its sequence numbers count bytes.

tf.q: The TCP specification requires the receiver to buffer out-of-order segments.
tf.correction: The TCP RFC does not mandate this; it is an implementation choice (though a common one).

tf.q: When calculating `EstimatedRTT`, TCP should include the RTT measurements from retransmitted segments.
tf.correction: To avoid ambiguity, measurements from retransmitted segments are ignored when calculating SampleRTT and EstimatedRTT.

tf.q: A `TimeoutInterval` that is too short can lead to unnecessary retransmissions.
Flow control is a mechanism to prevent the sender from overwhelming the network.
tf.correction: That is congestion control. Flow control prevents the sender from overwhelming the receiver.

tf.q: During a 3-way handshake, both the client and server choose their own initial sequence numbers.
The TCP 'Header Length' field is necessary because the header can contain a variable-length options field.
Scenario: If a sender receives an ACK with `rwnd=0`, it must stop sending all packets until a new ACK arrives.
tf.correction: The sender will stop sending data segments but can still send special 1-byte probe segments to check if the window has re-opened.

tf.q: Scenario: A sender receives three duplicate ACKs for `ACKnum=500`. It will immediately retransmit the segment that starts with byte 500.
Scenario: In the final step of the 3-way handshake, the client sends an ACK to the server. This ACK segment cannot contain any application data.
tf.correction: In many implementations, this final ACK can carry (piggyback) the first piece of application data.

tf.q: TCP's ACK is cumulative, meaning `ACK=X` acknowledges all data up to byte `X-1`.
The TCP 'FIN' flag is used to abruptly reset a connection.
tf.correction: The FIN flag is used for a graceful termination of a connection. The RST flag is used for an abrupt reset.

mcq.q: A................ network can guarantee certain amount of end-to-end bandwidth for the duration of a call.
................... hosts break application-layer messages into packets.
When host receives segments and direct it to the appropriate socket this is called………..
In rdt protocols, sequence numbers are used to…………
opts: c. Distinguish between new data or retransmission
d. To handle losses in channel
mcq.answer: c. Distinguish between new data or retransmission

mcq.q: A message in transport layer is called……….?
A message in Network layer is called……….?
A message in link layer is called……….?
A message in Physical layer is called……….?
A message in Application is called……….?
Amount of time, the sender is not idle but is sending data…….?
TCP protocol is............. protocol.
The layer responsible for the routing of datagrams from source to destination is?
File Transfer Protocol (FTP) is one of the ……
private network that connects its data centers to Internet, often bypassing tier-1, regional ISPs
In Client-Server Paradigm, the process which initiates the communication is?
… ..............Protocol belongs to the transport layer.
architecture refers to the organization of the communication process into layers (e.g., the five-layer Internet architecture).
In TCP, if the receiver “advertises” free buffer, so that the sender limits amount of unACKed (“in-flight”) data to received, this is called……
To handle data from multiple sockets and add transport header is called…………
By UDP, three segments from different hosts, all destined to the same IP address and same port number demultiplexed to ............................... socket/sockets.
opts: b. Can be different or same

mcq.q: rate (bits/time unit) at which bits are being sent from sender to receiver.
................... is private network that connects its data centers to Internet, often bypassing tier-1, regional ISPs.
SMTP is considered ……
Time for a small packet to travel from client to server and back is called……..
Applications that use TCP protocol.....
opts: A. Can tolerate some data loss but cannot tolerate large time delay.
B. Can tolerate some time delay but cannot tolerate data loss.
mcq.answer: B. Can tolerate some time delay but cannot tolerate data loss.

mcq.q: An identifier that specifies the identity of the receiving process on the destination host.
When you browse the world wide web you are using an application that follows...
A network application is a software application that can run on………....
File Transfer Protocol (FTP) is one of the ………….
… ......defines the format, order of messages sent and received among network entities, and actions taken on msg transmission, receipt.
Use header info to deliver received segments to correct socket.
Using TCP, three segments from different hosts , all destined to the same IP and same port number demultiplexed to ......................socket/sockets.
opts: c- Can be different or same

mcq.q: If the sender allows multiple, "in-flight", yet-to-be-acknowledged packets. This is called……...
- In TCP, the receiver buffer out-of-order packets in ………….
- In TCP, the receiver discard (drop) out-of-order packets in ………….
To agree to establish connection between sender and receiver by handshaking is called…….?
………. routers provide direct feedback to sending/receiving hosts with flows passing through congested router.
…...has responsibility of transferring datagram from one node to physically adjacent node over a link
To handle data from multiple sockets and add transport header is called……….
Use header info to deliver received segments to correct socket is called………

By UDP (Connectionless demultiplexing), three segments from different hosts, all destined to the same IP address and same port number demultiplexed to .......................................socket/sockets
opts: b. Can be different or same

mcq.q: By TCP (Connection-oriented demultiplexing), three segments from different hosts, all destined to the same IP address and same port number demultiplexed to............................socket/sockets
opts: b. Can be different or same

mcq.q: By UDP, two process from same application in same host, all destined to server with the same destination port number how many sockets host need in server to connect……………………….
By TCP, two process from same application in same host, all destined to server with the same destination port number how many sockets host need in server to connect ……………………….
When receiver send……… explicitly tells sender that pkt had errors
Sender adds ............. to each packet to handling duplicates packet
In TCP, if the receiver “advertises” free buffer, so that the sender limits amount of unACKed (“in-flight”) data to received, this is called……
too many sources sending too much data too fast for network to handle this is called……
Sender allows multiple, “in-flight”, yet-to-be-acknowledged packets this is called……
moves datagrams from input ports to output ports to transfer datagrams along end-end path this is Function of………………
To determine path taken by packets from source to destination is called……………
Moving packets from a router’s input link to appropriate router output link is called……………
underlying channel perfectly reliable no bit errors no loss of packets
underlying channel may flip bits in packet checksum (e.g., Internet checksum) to detect bit errors
sender waits “reasonable” amount of time for ACK retransmits if no ACK received in this time
Receiver compute checksum of received segment if computed checksum equals checksum field value…………….
Receiver compute checksum of received segment if computed checksum Not equals checksum field value…………….
Suppose A sends two TCP segments back-to-back to B. The first segment has sequence number 80; the second has sequence number 110. How much data is the first segment?
… .................. byte stream “number” of first byte in segment’s data
… .................. seq # of next byte expected from other side
TCP fast retransmit if sender receives...............additional ACKs for same data, resend unACKed segment with smallest seq #
… ............. receiver controls sender, so sender won’t overflow receiver’s buffer by transmitting too much, too fast
Problem half open connection (no client) found in ………..
… .......... is too many sources sending too much data too fast for network to handle”

To handle data from multiple sockets and add transport header is called……….
Use header info to deliver received segments to correct socket is called………

too many sources sending too much data too fast for network to handle this is called……

moves datagrams from input ports to output ports to transfer datagrams along end-end path this is Function of………………
To determine path taken by packets from source to destination is called……………
Moving packets from a router’s input link to appropriate router output link is called……………
underlying channel perfectly reliable no bit errors no loss of packets
underlying channel may flip bits in packet checksum (e.g., Internet checksum) to detect bit errors
sender waits “reasonable” amount of time for ACK retransmits if no ACK received in this time
Receiver compute checksum of received segment if computed checksum equals checksum field value…………….
Receiver compute checksum of received segment if computed checksum Not equals checksum field value…………….
Suppose A sends two TCP segments back-to-back to B. The first segment has sequence number 80; the second has sequence number 110. How much data is the first segment?
… .................. byte stream “number” of first byte in segment’s data
… .................. seq # of next byte expected from other side
TCP fast retransmit if sender receives...............additional ACKs for same data, resend unACKed segment with smallest seq #
… ............. receiver controls sender, so sender won’t overflow receiver’s buffer by transmitting too much, too fast
Problem half open connection (no client) found in ………..
… .......... is too many sources sending too much data too fast for network to handle”
…...has responsibility of transferring datagram from one node to physically adjacent node over a link
To handle data from multiple sockets and add transport header is called……….
Use header info to deliver received segments to correct socket is called………
……….no explicit feedback from network congestion inferred from observed loss, delay
… ............... routers provide direct feedback to sending/receiving hosts with flows passing through congested router
Which approach taken by TCP to congestion control……..
………increase sending rate by 1 maximum segment size every RTT until loss detected
… ................ is cut sending rate in half at each loss event
Sending rate is cut in half on loss detected by triple duplicate ACK is called ……….
Sending rate is cut to 1 MSS (maximum segment size) when loss detected by timeout called ……
TCP Reno sending rate is cut in half on loss detected by …………...
TCP Tahoe rate is cut to 1 MSS (maximum segment size) when loss detected by……….
TCP slow start when connection begins, increase rate exponentially until first loss event initially cwnd = ……………..
TCP slow start ..................... cwnd every RTT
The exponential increase switch to linear when cwnd gets to................of its value before timeout.
… ............... default in Linux, most popular TCP for popular Web servers

………… two bits in IP header (ToS field) marked by network router to indicate congestion
Retransmission of packets must not be done when
In Go-Back-N window, when the timer of the packet times out, several packets have to be resent even some may have arrived safe. Whereas in Selective Repeat window, the sender resends ………._
opts: a) Packet which are not lost
b) Only those packets which are lost or corrupted
mcq.answer: b) Only those packets which are lost or corrupted

mcq.q: In the slow-start algorithm, the size of the congestion window increases until it reaches a threshold.
In the congestion avoidance algorithm, the size of the congestion window increases until congestion is detected.

tf.q: Suppose a process in Host C has a UDP socket with port number 6789. Both Host A and Host B each send a UDP segment to Host C with destination port number 6789. (True/False, assuming they are directed to the same socket)
The Layer which is responsible for routing datagram from source to destination is transport layer.
tf.correction: The Network layer is responsible for routing.

tf.q: The Layer which is responsible for supporting network applications is application layer.
The Layer which is responsible for process-process data transfer is transport layer.
The Layer which is responsible for data transfer between neighboring network elements is link layer.
In Selective repeat Protocol, the sender retransmits packet n and all higher seq. no. in window after timeout of packet n.
tf.correction: This describes Go-Back-N Protocol.

tf.q: Applications that cannot tolerate loss should tolerate some delay and use TCP transport protocol.
An Internet Exchange Points (IXP) is a meeting point where multiple ISPs can connect and/or peer together.
network-core devices can run user applications.
tf.correction: Only end systems (hosts) run user applications.

tf.q: SMTP Protocol is used to retrieve emails from the mail server to clients.
tf.correction: SMTP is used to send (push) emails.

tf.q: The TCP protocol belongs to Application layer in TCP/IP protocol.
tf.correction: It belongs to the Transport layer.

tf.q: HTTP Protocol is one of the link layer protocols.
tf.correction: It is an Application layer protocol.

tf.q: In UDP, there is handshaking between sender and receiver to establish connection.
tf.correction: UDP is connectionless; TCP uses handshaking.

tf.q: link layer implemented in network interface card (NIC) or on a chip
Pipelining increases the utilization by 3 times, if the sender sends three in-flight packets yet-to-be- knowledge.
In TCP using the Go-Back-N, the receiver discards out-of-order packet
Sender sends one packet, and then waits for receiver response is called stop and wait protocol.
SMTP is both push & pull based protocol, so it can be used for downloading emails from mail server to clients
tf.correction: SMTP is a push protocol. POP3/IMAP are pull protocols.

tf.q: TCP socket identified by 4-tuples
Transport services and protocols provide logical communication between application processes running on different hosts
Transport services and protocols provide physical communication between application processes running on different hosts
tf.correction: They provide logical communication.

tf.q: Sender at transport layer in end systems breaks application messages into segments, passes to network layer
Receiver at transport layer in end systems reassembles segments into messages, passes to application layer
Receiver at transport layer in end systems breaks application messages into segments, passes to network layer
tf.correction: This is the sender's job.

tf.q: Sender at transport layer in end systems reassembles segments into messages, passes to application layer
tf.correction: This is the receiver's job.

tf.q: TCP, UDP both are two transport layer protocols available to Internet applications
Network layer is logical communication between hosts
Network layer is physical communication between hosts
tf.correction: It provides logical communication.

tf.q: Network layer is logical communication between processes
tf.correction: This is the Transport layer's job.

tf.q: Transport layer is logical communication between processes
Transport layer is physical communication between processes
tf.correction: It provides logical communication.

tf.q: Transport layer is logical communication between hosts
tf.correction: This is the Network layer's job. Transport is between processes.

tf.q: Sender is passed an application-layer message, determines segment header fields values, creates segment and passes segment to IP
Receiver is receiving segment from IP, checks header values, extracts application-layer message and demultiplexes message up to application via socket
Sender multiplexes message and send it to network layer
Receiver demultiplexes message up to application via socket
TCP is Transmission Control Protocol, reliable, in-order delivery, congestion control, flow control and connection setup
UDP is User Datagram Protocol, unreliable, unordered delivery, no-frills extension of “besteffort” IP
Delay guarantees and bandwidth guarantees services not available in TCP and UDP protocols
Multiplexing at sender is handle data from multiple sockets and add transport header
Multiplexing at receiver is handle data from multiple sockets and add transport header
tf.correction: This is the sender's job.

tf.q: Demultiplexing at receiver use header info to deliver received segments to correct socket
Demultiplexing at sender use header info to deliver received segments to correct socket
tf.correction: This is the receiver's job.

tf.q: Host uses IP addresses & port numbers to direct segment to appropriate socket
Host receives IP datagrams each datagram has source IP address, destination IP address, source port number and destination port number
TCP socket identified by 4-tuple source IP address, dest IP address, source port number and dest port number
TCP socket identified by 2-tuple source IP address and destination port number only
tf.correction: This describes UDP demux, not TCP.

tf.q: when creating datagram to send into UDP socket, must specify destination IP address and destination port number
UDP demultiplexing using destination port number and destination IP addresses (only)
tf.correction: It uses only the destination port number.

tf.q: TCP demultiplexing using 4-tuple: source and destination IP addresses, source and destination port numbers
Multiplexing/demultiplexing happen at all layers
IP/UDP datagrams with same dest. port #, but different source IP addresses and/or source port numbers will be directed to same socket at receiving host
In UDP, there is no flow control and no congestion control
acknowledgements (ACKs) receiver explicitly tells sender that pkt received OK
negative acknowledgements (NAKs) receiver explicitly tells sender that pkt had errors
Sender will retransmit packet again when receive of (NAKs)
Stop and wait protocol is sender sends one packet, then waits for receiver response
In stop and wait protocol if ACK/NAK corrupted sender doesn’t know what happened at receiver
In stop and wait protocol receiver cannot know if its last ACK/NAK received OK at sender
rdt2.1 receiver discard (doesn’t deliver up) duplicate pkt
rdt2.2 a NAK-free protocol same functionality as rdt2.1, using ACKs only
a NAK-free protocol is instead of NAK, receiver sends ACK for last pkt received OK
In rdt2.2 duplicate ACK at sender results in same action as NAK: retransmit current pkt
Rdt3.0 sender waits “reasonable” amount of time for ACK retransmits if no ACK received in this time
Pipelining increased utilization in network
Network layer protocols in every Internet device hosts, routers
Routers examines header fields in all IP datagrams passing through it
Forwarding is move packets from a router’s input link to appropriate router output link
Routing is determined route taken by packets from source to destination
Buffering occurs in router when arrival rate via switch exceeds output line speed
UDP is faster than TCP protocol
TCP Connection Establishment done in 3 way hand check
TCP Connection Termination done in 4 way hand check
The six bits in the Control Bits field of the TCP segment header are also known as flags
Sender retransmits pkt on receipt of NAK
Stop and wait is sender sends one packet, then waits for receiver response
utilization is fraction of time sender busy sending
pipelining is sender allows multiple, “in-flight”, yet-to-be-acknowledged packets
Go-Back-N sender cumulative ACKs all packets up to, including seq # n
Selective repeat receiver individually acknowledges all correctly received packets
UDP small header size and simple no connection state at sender, receiver
UDP use streaming multimedia apps (loss tolerant, rate sensitive), DNS, SNMP
UDP checksum used to detect errors (i.e., flipped bits) in transmitted segment
In Go-back-N protocol, if the acknowledgment of a frame is not received within an agreed upon time period, all frames starting from that frame are retransmitted
Go-back-N protocol provides for sending multiple frames before receiving the acknowledgment for the first time
The transport layer transports application layer message between the two communicating hosts using one of its two popular protocols TCP or UDP
Each TCP segment has source port number (SP) and destination port number (DP), host uses IP addresses & port numbers to direct segment to appropriate socket.
Server host may support many simultaneous TCP sockets and each socket identified by its own 4-tuple.
TCP full duplex data: bi-directional data flow in same connection
Sequence numbers: byte stream “number” of first byte in segment’s data
Acknowledgements: seq # of next byte expected from other side
TCP fast retransmit if sender receives 3 additional ACKs for same data (“triple duplicate ACKs”), resend unACKed segment with smallest seq #
TCP receiver “advertises” free buffer space in rwnd field in TCP header
Closing a TCP connection client, server each close their side of connection send TCP segment with FIN bit = 1
Congestion control too many senders, sending too fast
Flow control one sender send too fast for one receiver
link layer implemented in network interface card (NIC) or on a chip
In TCP using the Go-Back-N, the receiver discards out-of-order packet
TCP socket identified by 4-tuples

negative acknowledgements (NAKs) receiver explicitly tells sender that pkt had errors

TCP server can communicate with multiple clients using the same socket.
tf.correction: A new socket is created for each connection, identified by the 4-tuple.

tf.q: TCP socket is identified by only source IP address and destination IP address
tf.correction: It's identified by the 4-tuple (source/dest IP, source/dest port).

tf.q: In selective repeat protocol, if the acknowledgment of a frame is not received within an agreed upon time period, all frames starting from that frame are retransmitted
tf.correction: This describes Go-Back-N. Selective Repeat only retransmits the single lost packet.

tf.q: In Go-back-N protocol, if the acknowledgment of a frame is not received within an agreed upon time period, all frames starting from that frame are retransmitted
Go-back-N protocol provides for sending multiple frames before receiving the acknowledgment for the first time
The transport layer transports application layer message between the two communicating hosts using one of its two popular protocols TCP or UDP
Each TCP segment has source port number (SP) and destination port number (DP), host uses IP addresses & port numbers to direct segment to appropriate socket.
Server host may support many simultaneous TCP sockets and each socket identified by its own 4-tuple.
TCP full duplex data: bi-directional data flow in same connection
Sequence numbers: byte stream “number” of first byte in segment’s data
Acknowledgements: seq # of next byte expected from other side
TCP fast retransmit if sender receives 3 additional ACKs for same data (“triple duplicate ACKs”), resend unACKed segment with smallest seq #
Opening a TCP connection client, server each close their side of connection send TCP segment with FIN bit = 1
Congestion control too many senders, sending too fast
Flow control one sender send too fast for one receiver
When sender times can time out prematurely, sending two copies, both of which are delivered
Network-assisted congestion control routers provide direct feedback to sending/receiving hosts with flows passing through congested router
TCP congestion control AIMD senders can increase sending rate until packet loss (congestion) occurs, then decrease sending rate on loss event
Additive Increase is increase sending rate by 1 maximum segment size every RTT until loss detected
Multiplicative Decrease is cut sending rate in half at each loss event
In Multiplicative decrease sending rate is cut in half on loss detected by triple duplicate ACK called (TCP Reno)
In Multiplicative decrease sending rate is cut to 1 MSS (maximum segment size) when loss detected by timeout called (TCP Tahoe)
TCP slow start when connection begins, increase rate exponentially until first loss event
TCP slow start initial rate is slow, but ramps up exponentially fast
In slow start to congestion avoidance implementation of ssthresh is variable
In slow start to congestion avoidance on loss event, ssthresh is set to 1/2 of cwnd just before loss event
TCP CUBIC is there a better way than AIMD to “probe” for usable bandwidth
TCP CUBIC after cutting rate/window in half on loss, initially ramp to to Wmax faster, but then approach Wmax more slowly
TCP (classic, CUBIC) increase TCP’s sending rate until packet loss occurs at some router’s output called the bottleneck link
The transport layer is in the core of the layered network architecture. It has the critical role of providing communication services directly to the application processes running on different hosts.
tf.correction: The transport layer is in the end systems, not the network core.

tf.q: TCP CUBIC larger increases when further away from K
TCP CUBIC smaller increases (cautious) when nearer K
Explicit congestion notification (ECN) policy to determine marking chosen by network operator
TCP fairness if K TCP sessions share same bottleneck link of bandwidth R, each should have average rate of R/K
TCP is fair under idealized assumptions have same RTT and fixed number of sessions only in congestion avoidance
multimedia apps often do not use TCP
Fairness and UDP there is no “Internet police” policing use of congestion control
